summary: Authority for a teacher to dismiss a bad student.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to turn away (a pupil).

summary: Duty of a dismissed student to seek forgiveness.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, one who has been turned away should not not apologise.

summary: The "Nissaya" rule: mandatory dependence on a teacher for at least 5 years.
allowances: I allow, monks, an ignorant, inexperienced monk to live five years dependent...

Suspending the monk who started the dispute.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to carry out the Act of Suspension...

summary: Reuniting the Sangha after the dispute.
Reference to Devadatta's attempt to split the Sangha.
Dealing with disputes, quarrels, and the formal schism of the Sangha.
rules_prohibitions: Monks should not take sides in a dispute if it leads to schism. Suspending a monk who refuses to see his offense.
allowances: Allowed: To eat separately during a schism. Reconciliation (eating together) once the dispute is settled.

rules_prohibitions: Monks should not take sides in a dispute if it leads to schism. Suspending a monk who refuses to see his offense.
allowances: Allowed: To eat separately during a schism. Reconciliation (eating together) once the dispute is settled.

summary: Establishes the procedure for censuring monks who create strife and quarrels.
rules_prohibitions: It is not suitable, monks, it is not becoming in these foolish men, it is not fitting, it is not worthy of a recluse, it is not allowable, it is not to be done.
allowances: Well now, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of censure against the monks who are followers of Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka.

summary: A formal act of censure for a monk who causes arguments or disputes.
rules_prohibitions: A Community transaction... carried out against a bhikkhu not in his presence is invalid.
allowances: (The Community may carry out) a transaction of censure against a bhikkhu who is a maker of strife, a maker of quarrels, a maker of disputes...

summary: Applies the same 18 restrictions (as Censure) to the Act of Guidance.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, when a (formal) act of guidance has been carried out against a monk, he should conduct himself properly... he should not quarrel with monks.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Allows revocation of Guidance if the monk becomes learned and behaves well.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order revoke the (formal) act of guidance for the monk Seyyasaka.

summary: The formal motion for revoking the Act of Guidance.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked. Monks, the monk Seyyasaka... should speak thus to it: ‘I, honoured sirs, for whom a (formal) act of guidance was carried out by the Order, am conducting myself properly... I ask for the revocation of the (formal) act of guidance’.

summary: Establishes Banishment for monks corrupting families and engaging in bad habits.
rules_prohibitions: How, monks, can these foolish men indulge in bad habits such as these?
allowances: Do you go, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, and having gone to Kiṭāgiri, carry out a (formal) act of banishment from Kiṭāgiri against those monks who are followers of Assaji and Punabbasu.

summary: Banishing a monk from a specific monastery/area for bad behavior or corrupting lay families.
rules_prohibitions: (A bhikkhu under banishment) should not accept a regular bhikkhu's paying respect... he should not criticize the transaction.
allowances: (The Community may carry out) a transaction of banishment against a bhikkhu who is a corrupter of families, a man of depraved conduct.

summary: Lists qualities justifying banishment (frivolity, wrong livelihood, etc.).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if a monk is possessed of three qualities, an Order, if it so desires, may carry out a (formal) act of banishment against him: if he is a maker of strife... if he is possessed of bodily frivolity... verbal frivolity... wrong bodily mode of livelihood.

summary: Applies the 18 restrictions to banished monks.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk against whom a (formal) act of banishment has been carried out should conduct himself properly... he should not quarrel with monks.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Rules for when banishment should or should not be revoked.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, do not let the Order revoke the (formal) act of banishment (if they do not conduct themselves properly); Monks, if a monk is possessed of these eight qualities the (formal) act of banishment may be revoked.

summary: The formal motion for revoking Banishment.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked. Monks, that monk against whom the (formal) act of banishment has been carried out... should speak thus to it: ‘A (formal) act of banishment, honoured sirs, was carried out against me by the Order, but I am conducting myself properly... I ask for the revocation of the (formal) act of banishment’.

summary: Establishes Reconciliation for monks who insult faithful laypeople.
rules_prohibitions: How can you, foolish man, jeer at the householder Citta... with a low thing, and scoff at him with a low thing?
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of reconciliation for the monk Sudhamma, saying: ‘The householder Citta should be asked to forgive you.’

summary: Requiring a monk to apologize to laypeople he has insulted or harmed.
rules_prohibitions: (A bhikkhu under reconciliation) should not accept a regular bhikkhu's paying respect... he should not find fault with those who perform the transaction.
allowances: (The Community may carry out) a transaction of reconciliation against a bhikkhu who has striven for the material loss of householders... or spoken in dispraise of the Buddha, Dhamma, or Sangha.

summary: Criteria for a valid Act of Reconciliation.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if it is possessed of three qualities, a (formal) act of reconciliation comes to be a (formal) act that is legally valid.

summary: Defines the twelve cases where a formal act is invalid (e.g., done without the accused present).
rules_prohibitions: If, monks, a (formal) act of censure is possessed of these three qualities it comes to be not legally valid and not disciplinarily valid and one that is hard to settle.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Lists qualities justifying Reconciliation (harming laity).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if a monk is possessed of five qualities, the Order, if it so desires, may carry out a (formal) act of reconciliation for him: if he tries for non-receiving (of gains) by householders... reviles and abuses householders... speaks dispraise of the Awakened One to householders.

summary: Applies the 18 restrictions to monks undergoing Reconciliation.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk for whom a (formal) act of reconciliation has been carried out should conduct himself properly... he should not quarrel with monks.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Procedure for the monk to ask forgiveness from the layperson, with a companion.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order give a companion messenger to the monk Sudhamma to ask the householder Citta to forgive him.

summary: Revocation allowed if the monk behaves properly.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order revoke the (formal) act of reconciliation for the monk Sudhamma.

summary: Formal motion for revoking Reconciliation.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked... ‘I, honoured sirs, for whom a (formal) act of reconciliation was carried out by an Order, am conducting myself properly... I ask for the revocation of the (formal) act of reconciliation’.

summary: Establishes Suspension for refusing to acknowledge an offence.
rules_prohibitions: How, monks, can this foolish man, having fallen into an offence, not want to see the offence?
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of suspension against the monk Channa for not seeing his offence, (and there should be) no eating with an Order.

summary: Suspending a monk's rights (communion) for refusing to acknowledge or fix an offense, or holding wrong views.
rules_prohibitions: The Pātimokkha should not be recited when he is present; he is not allowed to participate in any Community transaction.
allowances: (The Community may carry out) a transaction of suspension against a bhikkhu for not seeing an offense... for not making amends for an offense... for not relinquishing an evil view.

summary: Criteria for Suspension.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if an Order so desires, it may carry out a (formal) act of suspension for not seeing an offence against these three (kinds of) monks.

summary: Severe restrictions (43 observances) for suspended monks, including loss of seniority rights.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk against whom a (formal) act of suspension for not seeing his offence has been carried out should conduct himself properly. This is proper conduct in this case: he should not ordain... he should not consent to a regular monk’s greeting him, standing up before him, saluting him with joined palms, performing the proper duties... he should not eat with an Order.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Revocation allowed if conduct improves.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks let the Order revoke the (formal) act of suspension for not seeing his offence against the monk Channa.

summary: Defines the twelve cases where a formal act is valid.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: If, monks, a (formal) act of censure is possessed of these three qualities it comes to be a (formal) act that is legally valid and a (formal) act that is disciplinarily valid and one that is easily settled.

summary: Motion for revoking Suspension.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked... ‘A (formal) act of suspension for not seeing an offence was carried out against me... I ask for the revocation’.

summary: Establishes Suspension for refusing to atone for an offence.
rules_prohibitions: How, monks, can this foolish man, having fallen into an offence, not want to make amends for the offence?
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of suspension against the monk Channa for not making amends for his offence, (and there should be) no eating with an Order.

summary: Establishes Suspension for refusing to give up a pernicious false view.
rules_prohibitions: How can you, foolish man, speak thus: ‘In so far as I understand dhamma taught by the Lord, it is that in following those things called stumbling-blocks by the Lord, there is no stumbling-block at all’?
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of suspension for not giving up a wrong view against the monk Ariṭṭha who was formerly a vulture-trainer, (and with) no eating with an Order.

summary: Applies 43 restrictions to Arittha.
rules_prohibitions: (Same restrictions as other Suspensions)
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Revocation allowed if view is abandoned.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order revoke the (formal) act of suspension for not giving up a wrong view.

summary: Motion for revoking Suspension.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked... ‘I ask for the revocation of the (formal) act of suspension for not giving up a wrong view’.

summary: Lists qualities (e.g., maker of strife, ignorant) that justify an act of censure.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if a monk is possessed of three qualities, an Order, if it so desires, may carry out a (formal) act of censure against him.

summary: Detailed list of 18 restrictions imposed on a censured monk.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, when a (formal) act of censure has been carried out against a monk, he should conduct himself properly. This is the proper conduct in this case: he should not ordain, he should not give guidance, a novice should not attend him, the agreement for him to exhort nuns should not be consented to, and even if he is agreed upon nuns should not be exhorted (by him), he should not fall into that (same) offence for which a (formal) act of censure came to be carried out against him by an Order, nor into another that is similar, nor into one that is worse, he should not find fault with the (formal) act, he should not find fault with those who carry out the (formal) act, he should not suspend a regular monk’s Observance, he should not suspend his Invitation, he should not issue commands, he should not set up authority, he should not ask for leave, he should not reprove, he should not make remember, he should not quarrel with monks.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Conditions under which the Order must not revoke the censure (if the monk is still misbehaving).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, if a monk is possessed of five qualities a (formal) act of censure should not be revoked.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Conditions under which the Order may revoke the censure (if the monk behaves properly).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if a monk is possessed of five qualities a (formal) act of censure may be revoked.

summary: The formal motion and procedure for revoking the act of censure.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: And thus, monks, should it be revoked: Those monks who are followers of Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka... should speak thus to it: ‘A (formal) act of censure, honoured sirs, was carried out against us by the Order; but we are conducting ourselves properly... and we ask for the revocation of the (formal) act of censure’.

summary: Establishes the Act of Guidance for monks who are ignorant or frequent bad company.
rules_prohibitions: It is not suitable, monks, it is not becoming in this foolish man, it is not fitting, it is not worthy of a recluse, it is not allowable, it is not to be done.
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act of guidance for the monk Seyyasaka, saying: ‘You should live in dependence’.

summary: Demoting a monk to "dependent" status (like a junior monk) due to incompetence or bad company.
rules_prohibitions: (A bhikkhu under demotion) should not give Acceptance; he should not give dependence; a novice should not attend to him.
allowances: (The Community may carry out) a transaction of demotion against a bhikkhu who is ignorant and inexperienced... saying 'You should live in dependence'.

summary: 94 duties/restrictions for probationers, including loss of seniority privileges relative to regular monks.
rules_prohibitions: A monk who is under probation, monks, should not consent to regular monks greeting him... he should not ordain... he should not walk in front of a regular monk, nor sit down in front of him.
allowances: I allow, monks, the mutual greeting, standing up before... treating of backs by massaging between monks who are under probation according to their seniority. I allow, monks, five things for monks under probation according to their seniority: Observance, Invitation, cloths for the rains, gifts (to the Order), rice.

summary: The 94 duties imposed on a monk undergoing probation for a concealed Sanghadisesa offense.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu under probation should not give Acceptance; he should not give dependence; a novice should not attend to him... he should not sit on a seat in front of a regular bhikkhu.
allowances: Allowed: The Uposatha, the Invitation, rain-bathing cloths, occasional gifts, food tickets (according to seniority among probationers).

summary: Defines what breaks the probation period (requires restarting or extending).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: There are three (kinds of) interruptions, Upāli, for a monk under probation: dwelling with; dwelling away, separated from; not announcing.

summary: Conditions that break the probation continuity, requiring the monk to restart or make up the night.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Three interruptions for a bhikkhu under probation: living together, living apart, not announcing.

summary: Mechanism to pause probation for legitimate reasons.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, to postpone probation... ‘I am postponing probation’—probation comes to be postponed.

summary: Mechanism to resume probation.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, to take up probation... ‘I am taking up probation’—probation comes to be taken up.

summary: Conduct for those restarting probation.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk who deserves to be sent back to the beginning should not stay in a residence under one roofing with a regular monk.
allowances: (Same allowances as probationers regarding seniority among themselves)

summary: Conduct for those awaiting Manatta.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk deserving mānatta (discipline) should not go from a residence where there are monks to a residence where there are no monks, except with a regular (monk), unless there is a danger.
allowances: (Same allowances as probationers)

summary: Conduct for those in Manatta (six nights of penance).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk undergoing mānatta (discipline) should announce it when he is incoming... he should announce it daily.
allowances: (Same allowances as probationers)

summary: The six-night penance period following probation, with stricter rules on travel (must be with a Sangha).
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu undergoing manatta should not go from a residence with bhikkhus to a residence without bhikkhus, except with a Community.
allowances: Allowed: To perform the duties of a probationer (but strictly announced daily).

summary: Defines what breaks the Manatta period.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: There are four (kinds of) interruptions, Upāli, for a monk who is undergoing mānatta (discipline): dwelling with; dwelling away, separated from; not announcing; going about with less than a group.

summary: Conduct for those who have finished Manatta but await the Abbhana (rehabilitation) ceremony.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk who deserves rehabilitation should not go from a residence where there are monks to a residence where there are no monks... except with a regular (monk).
allowances: (Same allowances as probationers)

summary: Procedure for a single unconcealed Sanghadisesa offence.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order inflict mānatta (discipline) for six nights on the monk Udāyin for the one offence... not concealed.

summary: Procedure for restoring the monk after Manatta.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well, then, monks, let the Order rehabilitate the monk Udāyin.

summary: Combining probation periods for multiple offences (takes the longest duration).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order grant this monk concurrent probation, its duration depending on whichever was the offence among these offences that was concealed for ten days.

summary: Grand aggregation probation for complex cases where new offenses occur during the rehabilitation process.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To grant concurrent probation for multiple offenses committed while already under probation.

summary: Used when the monk cannot remember the dates/duration of concealment.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order grant the purifying probation to this monk on account of those offences.

summary: A "clean slate" probation used when a monk cannot recall the specific details of his concealed offenses.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To grant purifying probation (when the bhikkhu does not remember the dates or number of offenses).

summary: What happens if a probationer disrobes, goes mad, etc.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, the probation of one who leaves the Order is not effective.
allowances: If he is ordained again, the earlier granting of probation is just as it was for him... he must do probation (for any portion of time) remaining.

summary: Probation duration equals concealment duration.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order impose probation for one day on the monk Udāyin on account of the offence... concealed for one day.

summary: Calculating the probation period based on how long the offense was hidden.
rules_prohibitions: If a bhikkhu conceals a Sanghadisesa offense, probation is imposed for the number of days the offense was concealed.
allowances: Allowed: To impose probation corresponding to the period of concealment.

summary: Manatta follows probation.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order inflict mānatta (discipline) for six nights on the monk Udāyin on account of the one offence... concealed for one day.

summary: Final restoration.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order rehabilitate the monk Udāyin.

summary: Handling accumulated concealed offences.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Let the Order impose probation for five days...

summary: Restarting probation if a new offence occurs.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order send the monk Udāyin back to the beginning on account of the one offence... not concealed, while (he was under probation).

summary: Restarting if offence occurs while deserving Manatta.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well, then, monks, let the Order send the monk Udāyin back to the beginning...

summary: Requirement for the accused to be present for legal acts.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a (formal) act of censure or guidance or banishment or reconciliation or suspension should not be carried out against monks who are not present. Whoever should carry one out, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: The requirement that the accused must be present for a legal verdict to be valid.
rules_prohibitions: A transaction should not be carried out against a bhikkhu in his absence.
allowances: Allowed: To settle the issue in the presence of the Sangha, the Dhamma, the Vinaya, and the individuals involved.

summary: Penalty for a monk who obstinately denies then admits then denies (prevarication).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order carry out a (formal) act for the decision for specific depravity against the monk Uvāḷa.

summary: Mutual dropping of charges for minor offences to restore harmony.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, a legal question such as this to be settled by the covering up (as) with grass.

summary: A method to end group strife where both sides admit fault generally to restore harmony.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To settle a dispute by 'covering it over with grass' (mutual confession without digging up details), except for heavy offenses.

summary: Delegating a difficult dispute to a committee of elders.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, to settle a legal question like this by means of a referendum (committee).

summary: Definitions of legal issues.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, there are these four kinds of legal questions: legal questions arising out of disputes, legal questions arising out of censure, legal questions arising out of offences, legal questions arising out of obligations.

summary: Using a vote (salaka) to decide an issue when a unanimous decision cannot be reached.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To settle an issue by the opinion of the majority... by distributing voting tickets.

summary: Procedures for taking votes.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, in order to convince these monks, three methods of taking votes: the secret, the whispering in the ear, the open.

summary: Exoneration for a pure monk falsely accused (Dabba).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order give a verdict of innocence to Dabba the Mallian who has remembered fully.

summary: Exonerating an Arahant (like Dabba) who is accused of a crime he could not commit.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To give a verdict of mindfulness (innocence) to a bhikkhu who is fully mindful and falsely accused.

summary: Exoneration for offences committed while insane.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Well then, monks, let the Order give a verdict of past insanity to the monk Gagga who is no longer insane.

summary: Absolving a monk of offenses committed during a period of mental illness.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To give a verdict of past insanity to a bhikkhu who committed offenses while insane but is now cured.

summary: Requirement for confession for a valid legal act.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a (formal) act... should not be carried out against a monk without his acknowledgement. Whoever should (so) carry (one) out, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Using voting tickets (salaka) when unanimity fails.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you monks, to settle this kind of legal question by the decision of the majority; A monk possessed of five qualities should be agreed upon as distributor of (voting) tickets.

summary: Prohibition on sensual rubbing against trees or using luxury bath tools; simple hand rubbing allowed.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu bathing should not rub his body against a tree. It is an offense of wrong doing.
allowances: Allowed: To use the hand (to rub the body).

summary: Prohibition on sensual rubbing against trees.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, while a monk is bathing he should not rub his body against a tree. Whoever should (so) rub it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Prohibition on bath tools; allowance for sick.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not bathe on a rubbing-board. Whoever should (so) bathe, there is an offence of wrong-doing; Monks, you should not bathe using a scrubber.
allowances: I allow, monks, one who is ill (to use) an unshaped scrubber.

summary: Prohibition on skull/gourd bowls.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not go about for almsfood (to be put) into a gourd... into a water-pot... a bowl made from a skull should not be carried.
allowances: I allow you, monks, a waste-tub.

summary: Allowances for sewing tools and Kathina frames.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, various kinds of small knives with handles should not be used... various kinds of thimbles should not be used.
allowances: I allow you, monks, a needle... a tube for (holding) the needles... a kaṭhina-frame... a thimble.

summary: Allowances for bags.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, a bag for medicine... a bag for sandals.

summary: Mandatory water strainer rule.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not go along a highway without a strainer. Whoever should (so) go, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow, monks, a strainer... a regulation waterpot... a double water-strainer... a filter.

summary: Mandatory use of water strainers to prevent killing small water-borne creatures.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu is not to travel on a road without a water strainer.
allowances: Allowed: A strainer, a ladle-strainer, a filter box... or (in absence) to determine a corner of the robe.

summary: Detailed construction allowances.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, a place for pacing up and down in, and a bathroom (sauna); I allow... a pipe for the steam... a chair for the bathroom... a privy... a cesspool... privy shoes.

summary: Detailed engineering allowances for building sanitary toilets (vacca-kuti).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: A privy, a cesspool, a floor of brick/stone/wood, a roof, a door...

summary: Prohibition on public nudity.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, one who is naked should neither greet nor be greeted by one who is naked... one who is naked should not drink (etc). Whoever should (so) drink, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: (*Note: Shoe rules appear in Mv.V but are refined in Cv protocols). General ban on footwear indoors/in monasteries.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu should not wear shoes in the monastery (unless ill).
allowances: Allowed: To wear shoes in the monastery if one's feet are split or if ill.

summary: Allowances for water infrastructure.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, a well... a cord for drawing water... a tank... a bathroom with a curving roof.

summary: Rules on mats and flowers.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not be away, separated from your pieces of cloth to sit upon for four months... you should not lie down to sleep on beds scattered over with flowers.
allowances: I allow you, monks, having taken the scents, to give the five-finger mark on the door.

summary: Prohibition on luxurious/shared eating arrangements.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not eat (leaning against) chased cushions... you should not eat from one dish nor drink from one beaker nor share one couch...
allowances: I allow, monks, a stand (for the bowl).

summary: Standardizing the maximum length of hair for monks.
rules_prohibitions: Long hair should not be worn. It is an offense of wrong doing.
allowances: Allowed: Hair of two months' growth or two fingerbreadths in length.

summary: Prohibition on jewelry.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, ear ornaments should not be worn, chains... bangles... armlets... bracelets... finger rings should not be worn. Whoever should wear (any of these things), there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Maximum hair length rules.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, long hair should not be worn. Whoever should wear it (long), there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow it to be of a two months’ growth or two finger-breadths (in length).

summary: Prohibition on vanity; allowances for medical needs.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a mark on the face should not be examined in a mirror or in a water-bowl. Whoever should (so) examine it, there is an offence of wrong-doing; Monks, the face should not be anointed.
allowances: I allow you, monks, on account of a disease, to examine a mark on the face in a mirror or in a water-bowl; I allow you, monks, on account of disease, to anoint the face.

summary: Prohibition on entertainment.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not go to see dancing or singing or music. Whoever should go, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Procedure for boycotting a layperson.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, if a lay-follower is possessed of eight qualities his bowl may be turned upside down: if he tries for non-receiving (of gains) by monks...
allowances: I allow you, monks, to turn a lay-follower’s bowl upside down... I allow you, monks, to set upright a lay-follower’s bowl.

summary: The formal act of boycotting a layperson (Vaddha) for slandering the Sangha.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To turn the bowl upside down (suspend relations) for a lay follower who brings loss to the Community... or speaks in dispraise of the Buddha, Dhamma, or Sangha.

summary: Rule against walking on white cloth unless asked for blessings.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not tread on a cloth carpeting. Whoever should tread on one, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow you, monks, when being asked by householders for good luck’s sake, to tread on a cloth carpeting.

summary: Miscellaneous allowances.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not make use of a (clay foot-) scrubber.
allowances: I allow, monks, a little jar and a broom... a fan and a palmyra-whisk.

summary: Rules on fans and sunshades.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a chowry-fan should not be used... Monks, a sunshade should not be used. Whoever should use one, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow, monks, three (kinds of) fans... I allow, monks, a sunshade to be used in a monastery and monastery precincts both by one who is ill and by one who is not ill.

summary: Staffs allowed only for the sick.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a walking staff with string on it should not be carried.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to give an agreement as to a walking staff to a monk who is ill.

summary: Allowance for a specific monk; general prohibition on eating regurgitated food.
rules_prohibitions: But, monks, one should not eat (anything), having brought it back from the mouth to outside of it.
allowances: I allow, monks, rumination for a ruminator.

summary: Detailed grooming rules.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, long nails should not be worn... you should not have your twenty (nails) polished... you should not have your beards trimmed... you should not have the hair of your bodies removed... you should not have grey hairs taken out.
allowances: I allow, monks, cutting of the nails... a razor, a whetstone... tweezers... an instrument for removing dirt from the ears.

summary: Hygiene rules for nails and teeth cleaning.
rules_prohibitions: Long toenails/fingernails should not be worn... tooth-wood should not be chewed (too long).
allowances: Allowed: To cut nails down to the flesh... to chew tooth-wood (up to 8 fingerbreadths).

summary: Prohibition on hoarding metal; allowance for bandages.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a store of copper goods, of bronze goods should not be made... Monks, you should not sit down lolling on outer cloaks.
allowances: I allow, monks, a bandage... a loom.

summary: Rules on belts and fasteners.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not enter a village without your waistband... various kinds of waistbands should not be worn... various kinds of buckles should not be worn.
allowances: I allow, monks, a waistband... a buckle.

summary: Prohibition on singing style; allowance for chanting.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, dhamma should not be sung with a long-drawn plain-song sound. Whoever should (so) sing it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow intoning.

summary: Mandatory tooth cleaning stick.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, there are these five disadvantages in not chewing tooth-wood... Monks, a long piece of tooth-wood should not be chewed.
allowances: I allow, monks, tooth-wood... to be eight finger breadths (in length) at the most.

summary: Safety rules regarding fire and trees.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a forest should not be set on fire... Monks, a tree should not be climbed.
allowances: I allow you, monks, if a forest fire is burning, to make a counter-fire... to climb a tree to the height of a man, and as high as you like in cases of distress.

summary: Prohibition on Sanskrit verse; instruction to use one's own dialect.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, the speech of the Awakened One should not be given in metrical form. Whoever should (so) give it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to learn the speech of the Awakened One according to his own dialect.

summary: Prohibition on learning non-Buddhist arts (Lokayata).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, metaphysics should not be learnt... Monks, worldly knowledge should not be learnt.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Rules on responding to sneezes.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, ‘Long life’ should not be said to one who has sneezed.
allowances: I allow you, monks, when (the phrase) ‘May you live (long), honoured sirs’ is being spoken to you by householders to say, ‘Long life’ (to them).

summary: Prohibition on garlic.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, garlic should not be eaten. Whoever should eat it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to eat garlic in the case of illness.

summary: Detailed rules for urinals and latrines.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you monks, to relieve yourselves at one side... I allow you, monks, a vessel... urinal shoes.

summary: General allowances for materials.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, all copper goods except a weapon; all wooden goods except a sofa, a divan, a wooden bowl, wooden shoes; all clay goods except a (clay-foot-) scrubber and a large earthen vessel.

summary: Prohibition on specific wool garments.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, woollen clothes with the fleece outside should not be worn. Whoever should wear them, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Rules for making fruit allowable (kappiya).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, mangoes should not be made use of. Whoever should make use of them, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to make use of fruit that in five ways is allowable for recluses: if it is damaged by fire, damaged by a knife, damaged by (one’s) nail, if it is seedless, and the fifth is if the seeds are discharged.

summary: Rules for "kappiya" (making fruit allowable) to distinguish monks from laypeople who harvest freely.
rules_prohibitions: Mangoes should not be consumed (unless made allowable).
allowances: Allowed: To consume fruit made allowable in five ways: damaged by fire, knife, nail, seedless, or seeds removed.

summary: Allowance for Paritta chanting and medical blood-letting.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you... to make a charm for the self for self-protection (Paritta); I allow you, monks, to let blood.

summary: Prohibition on castration.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, one should not cut off one’s own male organ. Whoever should cut it off, there is a grave offence.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Prohibition on luxury (gold/silver) or wooden bowls; standardization of bowl materials.
rules_prohibitions: A wooden bowl is not to be used. It is an offense of wrong doing.
allowances: Allowed: Two kinds of bowls: iron and clay.

summary: Prohibition on showing off psychic powers (after Pindola levitated).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a condition of further-men, a wonder of psychic power is not to be exhibited to householders. Whoever should exhibit them, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Prohibition on expensive/wooden bowls.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a wooden bowl should not be used. Whoever should use one, there is an offence of wrong-doing; Monks, a bowl made of gold should not be used...
allowances: I allow you, monks, two (kinds of) bowls: an iron bowl, a clay bowl.

summary: Practical rules to prevent rusting or breaking the alms bowl.
rules_prohibitions: A bowl should not be left in the sun with water in it... should not be left on a hard surface.
allowances: Allowed: To dry the bowl in the sun for a short time... to use a bowl stand.

summary: Rules for washing and drying bowls.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a bowl should not be put away with water in it... A bowl should not be laid aside in the heat...
allowances: I allow you, monks, to put away a bowl having dried it in the sun.

summary: Rules to prevent breaking bowls.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a bowl should not be laid aside at the edge of a solid bench... a bowl should not be hung up... should not be laid aside on a couch... on a lap... in a sunshade... a door should not be opened when one has a bowl in one’s hand.
allowances: I allow you, monks, a little prop for bowls; I allow you, monks, a bowl-stand... a bag for bowls... a strap at the edge, a thread for tying.

summary: Initial allowance for built lodgings.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, five (kinds of) abodes: a dwelling-place, a curved house, a long house, a mansion, a cave.

summary: The Buddha allows monks to use built lodgings (accepted from Anathapindika).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: Five kinds of dwellings: a vihara, a curved house, a long house, a mansion, a cave.

summary: Rules on displacing monks during meals or sickness.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk should not turn (another) away while a meal is yet unfinished... Monks, one who is ill should not be turned away... Monks, a lodging should not be reserved on (some slight) pretext.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to give a suitable sleeping place to one who is ill.

summary: Procedures for assigning rooms.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a monk should not be thrown out of a dwelling-place belonging to an Order by one who is angry, displeased.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to assign lodgings... I allow you, monks, to agree upon a monk... as assigner of lodgings.

summary: Establishing Sangha officials to manage property fairness.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: To appoint a lodging-assigner, a meals-distributor, a storekeeper, a robe-receiver...

summary: Limit on reserving rooms.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, two (lodgings) should not be reserved by one (monk).
allowances: I allow you, monks, to reserve it for the three months of the rains but not to reserve it for the dry season.

summary: Etiquette for Dhamma teaching and seating.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, when a newly ordained monk is reciting to sit down on a seat that is the same (height)... I allow you, monks, to sit down with those entitled to seats of an equal (height).

summary: Prohibition on selling or giving away heavy assets like land, buildings, and furniture.
rules_prohibitions: Heavy articles (garubhanda) belonging to the Community should not be disposed of. It is a Thullaccaya offense.
allowances: (None explicit)

summary: Heavy property cannot be alienated.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, these five things not to be disposed of should not be disposed of by an Order or by a group or by an individual—even if disposed of they are not (really) disposed of. Whoever should dispose of them, there is a grave offence. (Monastery, land, furniture, tools, building materials).
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Heavy property cannot be shared out.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, these five things not to be divided up should not be divided up... Whoever should divide them up, there is a grave offence.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Allowances for doors, windows, and security.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, a door... a doorpost and lintel... a bolt... a keyhole... three (kinds of) windows... drapery... shutters.

summary: Allowances for simple furniture; ban on luxurious high beds.
rules_prohibitions: High beds should not be used.
allowances: Allowed: A rectangular chair, a straw chair, a bench... bunk beds (if the upper bunk has a railing).

summary: Allowances for furniture; prohibition on high beds.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not lie down to sleep on high couches.
allowances: I allow, monks, a rectangular chair... a straw chair... supports for the couches.

summary: Establishment of Sangha officials.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, to agree upon... an issuer of meals... assigner of lodgings... keeper of the storeroom... superintendent of monastery attendants.

summary: Rules on painting and decoration.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not have a bold design made with figures of women, figures of men.
allowances: I allow, monks, whitewash, black colouring, red chalk... wreath-work, creeper-work.

summary: Allowances for roof materials.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, five (kinds of) roofings: a roofing of tiles, a roofing of stones, a roofing of plaster, a roofing of tiṇa-grass, a roofing of leaves.

summary: Allowances for various rooms and structures.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, a balustrade... a curtain... three (kinds of) inner rooms... a verandah, a covered terrace... an assembly hall... a hall for the drinking water.

summary: Seniority applies to persons, not to reserving communal property.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, what belongs to an Order should not be reserved according to seniority.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to put repairs in charge (of a monk); I allow, monks, greeting... the best seat... according to seniority.

summary: Communal property cannot be hogged by elders, but personal respect is paid by seniority (Partridge Jataka).
rules_prohibitions: Lodgings belonging to the Community should not be preempted by seniority.
allowances: Allowed: To respect seniority in greeting, rising, and seats (personal etiquette).

summary: Rules on who gets bowed to.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, there are these ten who are not to be greeted... These three, monks, are to be greeted.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Use of lay luxury furniture.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, except for the three: a sofa, a divan, a cotton quilt, to sit down on what is displayed by householders, but not to lie down on it.

summary: Narrative of Devadatta trying to enforce stricter asceticism to split the Sangha.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: (The Buddha rejects Devadatta's 5 points: dwelling in forests, begging food, wearing rag-robes, living at tree roots, vegetarianism).

summary: Devadatta's proposal.
rules_prohibitions: Enough, Devadatta... Whoever wishes, let him be a forest-dweller; whoever wishes, let him stay in the neighbourhood of a village...
allowances: (Rejection of Devadatta's 5 points).

summary: Warning against schism.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Enough, Devadatta, do not let there be a schism in the Order, for a schism in the Order is a serious matter.

summary: Quantitative definition of schism.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: If, Upāli, there is one on one side and two on another... this, Upāli, is dissension in an Order but not schism in an Order... Dissension in an Order, Upāli, as well as schism in an Order is (due to there being) nine or more than nine.

summary: Technical definition: Schism requires at least 9 fully ordained monks; dissension requires fewer.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Upali, a schism in the Community is defined by nine or more (bhikkhus)...

summary: Detailed arrival protocol.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, an incoming monk, thinking, ‘I will now enter a monastery,’ having taken off his sandals... should enter the monastery carefully and unhurriedly.

summary: The "Wat" (duties) for a monk arriving at a new monastery.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: He should take off his sandals... lower his umbrella... ask about drinking water... ask which lodging is his.

summary: Teacher-student duties.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: The one who shares a cell, monks, should conduct himself properly towards the preceptor... (detailed service duties).

summary: The detailed service duties (Upaṭṭhāka) between teacher and student.
rules_prohibitions: The pupil should treat the preceptor with respect... offer tooth-wood... receive the bowl.
allowances: (Reciprocal duties: the preceptor must teach and care for the pupil).

summary: Protocol for hosting.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, when a resident monk has seen an incoming monk who is senior, he should appoint a seat...

summary: The duties of a resident monk in receiving a guest.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: If the senior is the arrival, the resident should prepare a seat... take the bowl and robe... offer water.

summary: Protocol for leaving.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, when a monk is going away, having packed away his wooden goods... he may set out having asked (for permission) as to his lodgings.

summary: The duties of a monk when leaving a dwelling (securing property).
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: He should put away wooden articles... close windows and doors... ask permission (if anyone is present).

summary: Table manners.
rules_prohibitions: He should not sit down amid the houses encroaching (on the space intended) for monks who are elders... he should not sit down amid the houses having spread out his outer cloak.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to give thanks in a refectory.

summary: Etiquette for eating in a communal hall (seating, serving, cleaning).
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu should not sit encroaching on the elders... should not reject the new monks.
allowances: Allowed: To give thanks (anumodana) in the refectory.

summary: Almsround protocol.
rules_prohibitions: He should not enter too hastily, he should not leave too hastily...
allowances: Monks, if a monk when he is walking for almsfood thinks: ‘I will enter this village,’ having dressed himself... he may enter the village carefully and unhurriedly.

summary: Etiquette for collecting almsfood (Pindapata).
rules_prohibitions: He should be properly clad... eyes downcast... not swaying the body...
allowances: (Detailed protocol for entering the village, accepting food, and returning).

summary: Forest survival duties.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, a monk who is a forest-dweller... should set out drinking water... he should learn the positions of the lunar mansions.

summary: Cleaning protocol.
rules_prohibitions: He should not beat the lodgings near monks... he should beat the lodgings to leeward.
allowances: In whatever dwelling-place he is staying, if that dwelling-place is soiled, he should, if he is able, clean it.

summary: Sauna etiquette.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, on being hindered in (your use of) a bathroom by monks who are elders, having out of disrespect brought a quantity of sticks, a fire should not be made... nor, monks, having closed a doorway, should you sit down in the doorway.
allowances: Whoever goes first to a bathroom, if ashes have accumulated, should throw out the ashes.

summary: Toilet etiquette.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, if there is water you should not not rinse after relieving yourselves. Whoever should not rinse, there is an offence of wrong-doing; Monks, you should not relieve yourselves in a privy according to seniority.
allowances: I allow, you monks, to relieve yourselves according to the order of arrival; Whoever goes to a privy, standing outside should cough...

summary: Authority to suspend Pātimokkha.
rules_prohibitions: Nor, monks, should the Pātimokkha be heard by one who has an offence. Whoever (such) should hear it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to suspend the Pātimokkha for him who, having an offence, hears the Pātimokkha.

summary: Authority to stop the recitation if an impure monk is present.
rules_prohibitions: The Pātimokkha should not be listened to by one who has an offense. It is an offense of wrong doing.
allowances: Allowed: To suspend the Pātimokkha for an individual... stating 'This person has an offense'.

summary: Prohibition on frivolous suspension.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not, without ground, without reason, suspend the Pātimokkha for pure monks who have no offences. Whoever should (so) suspend it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Rules preventing frivolous suspension of the ritual.
rules_prohibitions: The Pātimokkha should not be suspended without ground.
allowances: Allowed: To suspend the Pātimokkha on valid grounds (e.g., seeing, hearing, or suspecting a Parajika offense).

summary: Guidelines for accusers.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Upāli, if a monk is reproving, willing to reprove another, when he has considered five states within himself may he reprove the other.

summary: Establishing the Uposatha days for gathering.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to gather together on the fourteenth, fifteenth and eighth days...

summary: Instituting the recitation of the code of rules every fortnight.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to carry out the Observance, to recite the Pātimokkha.

summary: Designating a specific building (Uposathagara) for the ceremony.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to agree upon an Observance-hall.

summary: Setting the legal boundary for the Sangha's unity.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, an Observance should not be carried out by an incomplete Order.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to agree upon a boundary (sīmā).

summary: Respect for the assembly space during formal acts.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not enter the boundary with sandals on.

summary: Allowing shortened recitation in times of danger.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to recite the Pātimokkha in brief.

summary: Foundation of the Nuns' Order.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: If, Ānanda, the Gotamid, Pajāpatī the Great, accepts eight important rules, that may be ordination for her.

summary: The founding of the Bhikkhuni Sangha upon acceptance of the 8 Heavy Rules.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhuni must respect a bhikkhu... must not spend Rains where there are no bhikkhus...
allowances: If Mahapajapati Gotami accepts these eight vows of respect, that will be her full Ordination.

summary: Prohibition on vanity/luxury for nuns.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, nuns should not wear long waistbands... flounces... should not have their loins rubbed... should not smear their faces... should not make (ointment marks)... should not carry a piece of felt.
allowances: I allow, monks, a nun (to have) a waistband going once round.

summary: Nuns' property stays with nuns.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, if a nun as she is passing away, should speak thus, ‘After I am gone, let my requisites be for the Order,’ in that case the Order of monks is not the owner, but they are for the Order of nuns.

summary: Nuns must give way to monks.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a blow should not be given to a monk by a nun. Whoever should give (one), there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: I allow, monks, that a nun, having seen a monk, should make way for him.

summary: Restrictions on bowl use (hiding babies or refusing alms).
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a foetus should not be taken away in a bowl by a nun... Monks, nuns having seen a monk, should not show (him) the base of a bowl, having turned it upside down.
allowances: I allow, monks, when a nun has seen a monk, having pulled out her bowl, to show it to him... having set it upright.

summary: Prohibition on looking at male organs.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, nuns should not look at a membrum virile. Whoever should look at one, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Hygiene allowances for menstruation.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, nuns should not sit down or lie down on stuffed couches and stuffed chairs (when menstruating)... Monks, nuns are not to wear a hip-string the whole time.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to give lodgings to nuns temporarily; I allow, monks, a household robe... a loin-cloth, a hip-string (when menstruating).

summary: Questions regarding female anatomy/disease.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow you, monks, to question a woman who is being ordained about twenty-four things that are stumbling-blocks.

summary: Standard procedure for nuns' ordination.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, ordination in the Order of monks after she has been ordained on the one side, and has cleared herself (in regard to the stumbling-blocks) in the Order of nuns.

summary: Initial allowance.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: I allow, monks, nuns to be ordained by monks.

summary: The procedure requiring ordination from both the Nuns' and Monks' orders.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit)
allowances: Allowed: Bhikkhunis to be ordained by the Community of Bhikkhus (after being ordained by the Community of Bhikkhunis).

summary: Vehicles restricted to sick nuns.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, a nun should not go in a vehicle.
allowances: I allow, monks, a vehicle for (a nun) who is ill... a palanquin, a sedan-chair.

summary: Special case for Addhakasi due to danger.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, you should not ordain through a messenger who is a monk.
allowances: I allow you, monks, to ordain even through a messenger (who is a competent nun).

summary: Safety rules: no forest dwelling, no living alone.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, nuns should not stay in a forest.
allowances: I allow her, monks, to look after him (her child) until he attains to years of discretion; I allow them, monks, having agreed upon one nun, to give her to that nun as a companion.

summary: Safety and etiquette rules regarding nuns' travel and dwellings.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhuni should not live in a forest... should not ride in a vehicle (unless ill).
allowances: Allowed: A temporary lodging for bhikkhunis... a vehicle for the sick.

summary: One chance only for nuns who leave for other sects.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Monks, whatever nun, wearing the saffron robes, goes over to the fold of a sect, on coming back should not be ordained.

summary: Bathing rules for nuns.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, nuns should not bathe with chunam... should not bathe with scented clay... should not bathe in a bathroom (sauna)... should not bathe at a ford for men.
allowances: I allow them, monks, the red powder of rice husks and clay... ordinary clay... to bathe at a ford for women.

summary: Monks do not bow to nuns.
rules_prohibitions: Monks, one should not carry out greeting, rising up for salutation and proper duties towards women. Whoever should carry out (one of these), there is an offence of wrong-doing.
allowances: (None explicit in this section)

summary: Rules defining the hierarchy: monks do not perform formal acts of respect to nuns.
rules_prohibitions: A bhikkhu should not bow down to a woman (bhikkhuni).
allowances: Allowed: To recite the Patimokkha to bhikkhunis (later amended to bhikkhunis reciting it themselves).

summary: Nuns follow monks' training where shared.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Those rules of training for nuns, Gotami, which are in common with those for monks, as the monks train themselves, so should you train yourselves...

summary: Criteria for determining true Dhamma.
rules_prohibitions: (None explicit in this section)
allowances: Whatever are the states... (that) lead to passionlessness... you should know definitely, Gotami: this is dhamma.

summary: Nuns manage their own Pātimokkha and confession.

allowances: I allow, monks, the Pātimokkha to be recited to nuns by nuns; I allow, monks, nuns’ offences to be acknowledged by nuns.

summary: Nuns manage their own legal acts.

allowances: I allow, monks, nuns to carry out (formal) acts on behalf of the nuns.

summary: Monks assist in settling nuns' disputes.

summary: Monks teach Vinaya to nuns.
